ratingGuide.guidance: Dedicated startup/founder visa completed fully online, approvals within 4 weeks, <= USD 10k proof-of-funds, and no local sponsor.
Clear entrepreneur permit with remote steps, <= 8-week processing, and < USD 25k capital plus multi-year residence.
Predictable pathway resolved in <= 12 weeks, <= USD 50k capital, and documentation a startup lawyer can handle.
Business visa workable but requires in-person biometrics, background checks, and roughly 3-4 month timelines.
Route exists yet demands >= USD 75k capital, incubator sponsorship, and 4-6 month, multi-agency reviews.
Eligibility is defined but approvals are inconsistent, interviews are common, and timelines exceed 6 months.
Quotas, cultural tests, or payroll guarantees make approvals rare unless the studio already employs many locals.
Only high-investment (>= USD 250k) or acquisition-based visas are available; indie studios seldom qualify.
Program exists on paper but rejection rates are near total because of local ownership or job-creation mandates.
No realistic entrepreneurship visa path for a new, foreign-owned game studio.
Single digital tax portal, < 10 compliance hours per year, and payroll/VAT handled automatically.
Quarterly digital filings with predictable deadlines, < 20 hours per year, and outside accountants are optional.
Monthly payroll submissions exist but software covers most tasks (< 40 hours per year).
Monthly payroll and VAT plus occasional in-person steps, totaling roughly 40-60 hours per year with a fractional accountant.
Multiple agencies, translations, or notarizations drive compliance effort to 60-90 hours per year.
Constant document updates, payroll and benefits processed manually, > 90 hours per year, and an accountant is mandatory.
Frequent audits or surprise filings require the founder to coordinate several vendors all year.
Paper-based or in-person approvals dominate and consume > 150 hours per year plus legal review.
Compliance needs a full-time admin or outsourced controller because fines trigger weekly filings.
Environment is functionally hostile; filings are unpredictable and penalties are unavoidable.
25-34 AA studios with visible pipelines and hiring.
12-17 AA studios; community can support several partnerships.
5-7 AA studios; talent pool exists but is limited.
Exactly 2 AA studios on the ground.
>= 10 active AAA studios shipping titles from the region.
8-9 AAA studios with multiple teams and hiring pipelines.
6-7 AAA studios anchoring the talent market.
0 AAA studios but a confirmed AAA expansion is publicly announced.
No AAA studios or credible announcements.
>= 4 recurring in-person events per month, >= 2 jams or conferences per quarter, and 1,000+ active online members.
3 in-person events per month, a quarterly jam, and 700-999 engaged online members plus mentorship or incubator tracks.
2 events per month, >= 2 jams per year, and 400-699 online members with sponsor support.
Monthly meetups, >= 1 jam per year, and 250-399 online members driving collaborations.
6-11 events per year, 150-249 online members, and occasional jams with > 40 attendees.
Quarterly events and a 100-149 person online hub focused on hiring or co-working tips.
A couple of events per year and < 100 online members; leadership changes frequently.
Ad-hoc gatherings only when visiting organizations sponsor something; < 60 online members.
One-off coffee chats and no open online community.
<= USD 0.80M yearly burn; maximizes runway for an unfunded studio.
> USD 1.40M yearly burn; unsustainable for our profile.
<= USD 25k per year for 10-person office space.
0% but alternative micro-grants or pilots exist with heavy gating.
0% and no reliable incentive applicable to our projects.
>= 70% of the budget qualifies for incentives.
Visa filing is straightforward and evaluations have a quick turnaround with minimal evidence required.
Clear rules, responsive processing, and most steps can be done online within 2â€“3 months.
Predictable documentation and 3â€“4 month processing; attorney helpful but not mandatory.
Manageable but requires organized evidence and possibly an interview; 4â€“6 month timeline.
Moderate friction, periodic in-person steps, and 6â€“8 month timelines.
Lengthy or quota-driven processing with notable uncertainty; 8â€“12 months common.
Complex criteria, frequent RFEs, and high rejection risk without expert counsel.
Opaque or discretionary process that is difficult for skilled migrants to navigate.
Approvals for similar skilled migrants are rare; timelines exceed a year.
No practical immigration path for the family profile.
<10% of government, healthcare, and banking interactions require the local language; certified interpreters are available 24/7.
10-20% of critical admin tasks require the local language; most tax, visa, and healthcare forms have official English versions.
20-30% of interactions require the local language; English help desks cover the remainder.
30-40% of interactions require the local language; English is accepted for routine services but not for legal filings.
40-50% of interactions require the local language; English is usable mainly with multinational employers.
50-60% of interactions require the local language; English support exists but often requires paid interpreters.
60-70% require the local language; English assistance is limited to select agencies.
70-80% require the local language; English use is tolerated only in tourist or expat districts.
80-90% require the local language; English is rarely available outside large corporations.
>90% require the local language; English is effectively unsupported for official matters.
>=80% of public K-12 seats offer full English or dual-language tracks starting in kindergarten.
70-79% of seats offer bilingual programs beginning by grade 1.
60-69% of seats offer bilingual options beginning by grade 2.
50-59% of seats offer bilingual options beginning by grade 3.
40-49% of seats offer bilingual options beginning by grade 4.
30-39% of seats offer bilingual options beginning by grade 5.
20-29% of seats offer bilingual options beginning by grade 6.
10-19% of seats offer bilingual options and they begin after grade 6.
<10% of seats offer bilingual instruction and only in upper grades.
No public bilingual/English options; private schools are the only pathway.
Skilled visa approval rate >=95% and national polls show >=70% of residents view skilled immigration positively.
Approval rate 55-59% with <30% positive polling and rising opposition.
Approval rate <55% plus persistent negative polling and policy backlash.
Median lease secured in <=2 weeks with a single month deposit and digital paperwork only.
Lease in 2-3 weeks; <=1.5 months deposit; translator rarely required.
Lease in 3-4 weeks; <=2 months deposit; notarized documents minimal.
Lease in 4-6 weeks; <=2.5 months deposit; guarantor commonly requested.
Lease in 6-8 weeks; 3 months deposit; multiple in-person visits needed.
Lease in 8-10 weeks; 3 months deposit plus income certification.
Lease in 10-12 weeks; >3 months deposit and guarantor mandatory.
Lease in 12-16 weeks; >4 months deposit or multi-year commitment.
Lease in 16-20 weeks; limited inventory requires waiting lists.
>20 weeks average wait or legal barriers prevent most foreign tenants.
Placement guaranteed within 1 month for infants and preschoolers.
Placement typically in 1-2 months with transparent queue tracking.
Placement in 2-3 months; waitlists move weekly.
Placement in 3-4 months; parents must confirm monthly.
Placement in 4-6 months with periodic documentation refresh.
Placement in 9-12 months; limited infant seats.
Placement in 12-15 months; many families rely on private stopgaps.
Placement in 15-18 months; public seats extremely scarce.
>18 months average wait and no guarantee of placement.
Net daycare tuition <=EUR/USD 500 per month for a non resident child.
Net daycare tuition <=EUR/USD 350 per month for a permanent resident child.
Net daycare tuition <=EUR/USD 250 per month for a citizen child.
Median wait <1 day for primary care and <5 days for specialists.
1-2 day wait for primary care; 5-7 days for specialists.
3-4 day wait for primary care; 8-10 days for specialists.
5-7 day wait for primary care; 11-14 days for specialists.
8-10 day wait for primary care; 15-20 days for specialists.
11-14 day wait for primary care; 21-28 days for specialists.
15-20 day wait for primary care; 29-35 days for specialists.
21-28 day wait for primary care; 36-45 days for specialists.
29-45 day wait for primary care; >45 days for specialists.
>45 day wait for primary care and >60 days for specialists.
Family healthcare costs (premiums plus typical out-of-pocket) <=EUR/USD 1,000 per month for non residents.
>EUR/USD 3,200 per month or highly volatile billing.
Monthly costs <=EUR/USD 800 with permanent resident coverage.
<5% of residents would lose baseline coverage when leaving an employer.
5-10% at risk of losing coverage when job changes.
>80% tied to employer and little safety net.
>=90% of residents live within 500 m of service running every <=10 minutes for 18+ hours/day.
80-89% within 500 m of 10-minute headways for 18 hours/day.
70-79% within 500 m of 10-minute headways for 16 hours/day.
60-69% within 500 m of 12-minute headways for 16 hours/day.
50-59% within 500 m of 12-minute headways for 14 hours/day.
40-49% within 500 m of 15-minute headways for 14 hours/day.
30-39% within 500 m of frequent service; rest drive.
<10% within 500 m of reliable transit; service is sparse.
>=300 days per year with daytime highs 50-85°F and humidity <70%.
<60 comfortable days per year due to heat, cold, or humidity.
Typical winter highs 45â€“60Â°F and lows 32â€“45Â°F; little snow/ice.
Highs 40â€“55Â°F, lows 28â€“40Â°F with occasional light snow.
Highs 30â€“45Â°F, lows 20â€“32Â°F; regular frost and some snow.
Highs 10â€“25Â°F, lows âˆ’10â€“10Â°F; heavy snow and deep freezes common.
Highs below 20Â°F, lows below âˆ’10Â°F for extended periods.
Severe arctic winters with extreme cold and heavy snow dominating daily life.
Highs 55â€“72Â°F, lows 45â€“55Â°F; mostly mild with light rain.
Highs 50â€“68Â°F, lows 38â€“48Â°F; mixed sunny and cool days.
Highs 40â€“58Â°F, lows 30â€“40Â°F; unstable with cold snaps.
Highs under 55Â°F, lows under 35Â°F for much of spring.
Spring remains cold and wet with few comfortable days.
Highs 70â€“82Â°F, lows 60â€“70Â°F; low humidity and rare heatwaves.
Highs 72â€“85Â°F, lows 60â€“72Â°F; occasional short heat spikes.
Highs 85â€“97Â°F, lows 70â€“80Â°F with extended humid periods.
Highs 88â€“100Â°F, lows 72â€“82Â°F; long, oppressive heat stretches.
Highs often above 100Â°F with high humidity; relief is rare.
Extreme heat dominates summer, making outdoor life difficult.
Highs 50â€“70Â°F, lows 40â€“50Â°F; occasional warm or cool swings.
Highs 50â€“68Â°F, lows 38â€“48Â°F; mix of mild and chilly days.
Highs 48â€“65Â°F, lows 36â€“46Â°F; rain and wind are common.
Highs 42â€“60Â°F, lows 32â€“42Â°F; early cold snaps appear.
Highs under 55Â°F, lows under 35Â°F for much of fall.
Fall is short and quickly shifts to winter-like cold.
>=50% of land within 60 minutes is protected parkland or coastline plus >=5 nationally recognized scenic sites.
40-49% protected land within 60 minutes plus 3-4 scenic sites.
30-39% protected land within 60 minutes plus >=2 scenic sites.
25-29% protected land within 60 minutes plus at least 1 scenic reserve.
20-24% protected land within 60 minutes; scenic areas require short travel.
15-19% protected land within 60 minutes; limited signature vistas.
10-14% protected land; most scenery requires 2+ hours of travel.
5-9% protected land; scenic spots are isolated.
<1% protected land or heavy environmental degradation.
>=12 parks >10 acres within 5 km plus >=4 regional trails reachable by transit in under 30 minutes.
10-11 parks >10 acres within 5 km plus 3 regional trails within 30 minutes.
8-9 parks >10 acres within 5 km plus 2 regional trails.
6-7 parks >10 acres within 5 km plus 1 regional trail.
5 parks >10 acres within 5 km; regional trails require car trips under 45 minutes.
4 parks >10 acres within 5 km; regional trails require 45-60 minutes.
3 parks >10 acres within 5 km; regional trails >60 minutes away.
2 parks >10 acres within 5 km; few trail options.
1 park >10 acres within 5 km; no formal trail network.
No sizable parks within 5 km; nature outings require day trips.
Ultra-processed (NOVA 4) foods <15% of caloric intake, >6 permanent fresh food halls/markets per 100k residents, and <0.5 fast-food chains per 10k residents.
Ultra-processed share 15-19%, >5 permanent markets per 100k, <0.7 fast-food outlets per 10k.
Ultra-processed share 20-24%, >4 fresh markets or weekly farmers markets per 100k, <1 fast-food outlet per 10k.
Ultra-processed share 25-29%, at least 3 markets/CSAs with daily produce, <1.2 fast-food outlets per 10k.
Ultra-processed share 30-34%, 2-3 farmers markets or co-ops supplying fresh staples, <1.5 fast-food outlets per 10k.
Ultra-processed share 35-39%, at least 2 dependable produce vendors but heavy packaged presence, <1.8 fast-food outlets per 10k.
Ultra-processed share 40-44%, only 1 recurring farmers market or produce co-op, fast-food density <2.2 per 10k.
Ultra-processed share 45-54%, monthly or seasonal markets only, 2.2-2.8 fast-food outlets per 10k.
Ultra-processed share 55-64%, fresh produce mostly through supermarkets with limited variety, >=3 fast-food outlets per 10k.
Ultra-processed share >=65%, convenience/fast-food venues outnumber produce markets >4:1, little cultural emphasis on fresh cooking.
>=80% of trips are completed by walking, cycling, or transit; car lanes are traffic-calmed.
<20% of trips are car-free; car dependency dominates.
>=30 indoor/outdoor child-friendly venues per 100k residents open after 6 p.m. with staff supervision.
No reliable parent-friendly 3rd places after school hours.
5-year real GDP per capita standard deviation <1%.
Violent crime <200 incidents per 100k residents plus reliable utilities and schooling continuity.
>=900 incidents per 100k or persistent service disruptions.
<=5 severe weather or AQI>150 days per year.
<=1 major immigration policy overhaul per decade and <1% skilled approvals revoked.
Public tuition <=5% of median household net income with admission rate >=75% for desired programs.
Tuition 6-7% of income with admission rate 70-74%.
At least two universities rank within the global top 50 and >50% of advanced programs are available in English.
Top campus ranks 51-100 globally with >40% English programs.
Top campus ranks 101-150 with >35% English programs.
Top campus ranks 151-200 with >30% English programs.
Top campus ranks 201-300 with >25% English programs.
Top campus ranks 301-400 with >20% English programs.
Top campus ranks 401-500 with >15% English programs.
Top campus ranks 501-700 with >10% English programs.
Top campus ranks 701-900 with >5% English programs.
No university in global top 900 and English programs rare.
>=20 accredited adult upskilling programs per 100k residents plus subsidized online options.
>=25 senior .NET architect postings per million residents per month with median salaries in the top national quartile.
21-24 postings per million residents per month.
17-20 postings per million residents per month.
13-16 postings per million residents per month.
9-12 postings per million residents per month.
6-8 postings per million residents per month.
4-5 postings per million residents per month.
2-3 postings per million residents per month.
1 posting per million residents per month.
>=35 Rails developer postings per million residents per month with multiple employers hiring concurrently.
30-34 postings per million residents per month.
25-29 postings per million residents per month.
20-24 postings per million residents per month.
15-19 postings per million residents per month.
10-14 postings per million residents per month.
7-9 postings per million residents per month.
4-6 postings per million residents per month.
1-3 postings per million residents per month.
School meals score >=90 on the Healthy Eating Index (HEI) or equivalent, with <5% of calories from ultra-processed foods.
HEI <50 and/or >35% of calories from ultra-processed foods.
Students receive >=20 hours/week of English instruction plus bilingual aides in all subjects.
16-19 hours/week of English instruction with bilingual support in core subjects.
14-15 hours/week of English instruction with bilingual aides in language-heavy subjects.
12-13 hours/week of English instruction with some bilingual support.
10-11 hours/week of English instruction; bilingual aides limited.
8-9 hours/week of English instruction; translation provided only on request.
6-7 hours/week of English instruction; most homework in local language.
4-5 hours/week of English instruction; bilingual aides rare.
2-3 hours/week of English instruction; classes primarily in local language.
No English instruction in public schools beyond foreign-language elective.
>=150 subsidized language-course seats per 100 newcomers annually plus official translation at all agencies.
120-149 course seats per 100 newcomers and translation for most agencies.
100-119 course seats per 100 newcomers; translation for critical services.
80-99 course seats per 100 newcomers; translation via request.
60-79 course seats per 100 newcomers; limited translation.
40-59 course seats per 100 newcomers; classes fill quickly.
25-39 course seats per 100 newcomers; translation volunteers only.
10-24 course seats per 100 newcomers; sporadic translation support.
<10 course seats per 100 newcomers; translation rarely available.
No subsidized language courses or translation programs.
<1 reported incident per 1,000 students/workers with mandatory anti-bias training and swift enforcement.
7-8 incidents per 1,000; few resources for victims.
Monthly rent for a 150m2 home is <=EUR/USD 2,500 equivalent.
>EUR/USD 7,500 per month or inventory rarely available.
Monthly rent for a 150m2 home is <=EUR/USD 2,500 equivalent.
>EUR/USD 7,500 per month or inventory rarely available.
Monthly rent for a 150m2 home is <=EUR/USD 2,500 equivalent.
>EUR/USD 7,500 per month or inventory rarely available.
Family meal (two adults, two kids) averages <EUR/USD 45 including drinks.
Annual out-of-pocket cost <=EUR/USD 500 thanks to public coverage.
>EUR/USD 5,000 per year or sessions unavailable in English.
Net cost <=EUR/USD 200 for a 3-day stay including meds.
Tuition and mandatory fees <=EUR/USD 3,000 per semester.
Digital-by-default registration, translation support, and one-stop gov portals keep everyday compliance tasks under an hour per month.
Most filings completed online with modest queues; occasional in-person visit needed but handled in a single morning.
Mix of paper and online workflows; families spend several afternoons per quarter managing forms and in-person stamps.
Fragmented offices, limited English support, and repeated document requests consume multiple full days per quarter.
Highly manual processes with unpredictable delays; compliance requires persistent follow-up and often local fixer help.
